dataset.title: Application of a Pilot-Scale Pulsed Electrocoagulation System to OCC-Based Paper Mill Effluent

creator.organizationName: Division of Wood Cellulouse,Taiwan Forestry Research Institute

abstract.para: There are increasing trends toward closure of white water recirculation loops in papermaking often leading to needs for system modifications. A pilot-scale study was conducted using pulsed electrocoagulation technology to treat the effluent of an old corrugated containerboard (OCC)-based paper mill, with the purpose of evaluating its treatment performance. The operating variables were a current density of 0~240 A/m2, a hydraulic retention time (HRT) of 8~16 min, and a coagulant (anionic polyacrylamide) dosage of 0~22 mg/L. Water quality indicators investigated were electrical conductivity, suspended solids (SS), chemical oxygen demand (COD), and true color. The results obtained during pilot-scale studies were encouraging. Under the operating conditions without coagulant addition, the highest removals for conductivity, SS, COD, and true color were 39.8%, 85.7%, 70.5%, and 97.1%, respectively (with an HRT of 16 min). The use of a coagulant enhanced the removal of both conductivity and COD. With an optimal dosage of 20 mg/L and a shortened HRT of 10 min, the highest removals achieved for the four water quality indicators were 37.7%, 88.7%, 74.2%, and 91.7%, respectively. The water qualities thus attained should be adequate to allow reuse of at least substantial portion of the treated effluent as process water makeup in papermaking.

intellectualRights.para: 欲使用本文獻請徵詢作者同意

section.title: MATERIALS AND METHODS
section.para: The wastewater used in the experiments was mill discharge effluent treated in an activated sludge unit and a final sedimentation unit. As there were substantial variations in the water quality measurements even from moment to moment, in order to avoid the effects of such variations on the treatment results, a combined effluent of 1000 L was equalized in a homogenization tank before use in each set of experiments.

Figure 1 presents a schematic diagram of the treatment system used in the study. The system was composed of a perfectly mixed homogenization tank of 1000 L, a 65-L pilot-scale pulsed electrocoagulation reactor; a 78-L aerator; a 100-L flocculation tank, allowing the floc sufficient time to grow; and a 120-L sedimentation unit.

A pulsed electrochemical reactor (Model JC-10) developed by Jye-shi Environmental Technologies and Engineering (Chungho, Taiwan) was used in the study. The reactor is shown in Fig. 2 and is capable of treating 0.1~0.5 m3/h of wastewater with an HRT of 0.13~0.65 h.

There are 16 electrolytic cells inside the reactor, separated by cast iron plates which served as electrodes. Figure 3 shows the setup of the electrodes. For the reactor, the relationship between current density and voltage is indicated in Table 1. The operational current density for the reactor was between 40 and 240 A/m2, and the electrical potential per cell was 2.3~8.3 V.

Untreated wastewater was first pumped into the homogenization tank for equalization. Then each set of experiments was carried out with 1000 L of equalized wastewater that was fed to the reactor for treatment. Further, the treated wastewater passed through an aerator and flocculation tank, and then flowed into a sedimentation unit for sludge settling. Air was supplied to the aerator by a 3-hp compressor and air diffuser. Based on a particular set of operating conditions chosen, polymer coagulant (an anionic polyacrylamide) was added to the flocculation tank. The sludge settled in the sedimentation unit was collected and subsequently dewatered.

During operation, the polarity of the electrodes was switched every 30~60 s to avoid excessive iron plate erosion. The switching of polarity also produced a pulsed effect that caused dipole inductions in non-polar insoluble substances in the wastewater.

Three sets of experiments were conducted, with each set being performed with one specific HRT, four current densities, and three coagulant dosages; excluding the conditions of zero current density and zero coagulant dosage, each set contained 25 experiments.

The values of the three operating variables studied were current densities of 0, 40, 107, 187, and 240 A/m2; HRTs in the reactor of 0, 8, 10, and 16 min; and coagulant dosages of 0, 9, and 22 mg/L. The temperature and pH were not controlled in any of the experiments, because these two parameters varied with the untreated wastewater quality, HRT, and the current density applied. Consequently, the operative pH ranged between 7.6 and 8.0, and the temperature varied between 22.1 and 29.4 °C.
Instruments and Methods for Chemical Analyses

A Suntex (NIEA W203.51) BSC-170 conductivity meter was used for conductivity, an NIEA model W210.56A was used for SS; an NIEA W517.50B model was used for COD; a Hach model 2100P (NIEA W219.51C) was used for turbidity; a Mettler-Toledo MP220 (NIEA W217.51A) was used for pH; and a Hach model DR/4000, with a wavelength range of 190~1100 nm and wavelength accuracy of ± 1 nm (NIEA W223.50B), was used to measure true color.

The electrical conductivity, SS content, COD, turbidity, pH, and temperature of the equalized wastewater were measured before and after treatment. Measurements of iron contents of untreated and treated wastewaters were made for a set of experiments run at different current densities for a fixed HRT and without the addition of coagulant.
